instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> suck at 5V - 0.01A
threads.message:
Hello everyone, I'm new to this forum.

I got an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> stuck in 5V and 0.1 A
I do daily motherboard repair, but I really have to fix this one for data recovery so there is no better place to get replies than Rossmann forum.

I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V so present, and none of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has loop going on.
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> is 5V on every port and is an issue that I never found in my logic board repair. 

The machine didn't have Water damage, and looks perfect.

any suggestion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> suck at 5V - 0.01A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3V so present"
It is present, or not?
Also post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage; diode mode to ground, if no present.

Be aware, this board doesn't turn on without 87W charger, if no good battery is connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> suck at 5V - 0.01A
threads.message:
I knew the 87W charger information but thanks. I was already using 96W.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  is 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.25V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> suck at 5V - 0.01A
threads.message: replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and fixed it. Thanks anyway :)
